It is one thing to add enrichment material AFTER children have learned their addition and multiplication tables.
But it is totally wrong and educationally unproductive to claim that learning these enrichment concepts can substitute for learning those tables.

Unfortunately there is no model for the government paying the quants anything remotely resembling what they can make in the private sector and we do not have the kind of society where most people can justify the risks to themselves and their families of not earning what the market will pay.

Lucius transcends age, they burst through hipster barriers and smash youthful ideologies of what music might be. Lucius reminds generations of why they used to fall desperately in love with a lyric. They are beautiful and real. Can't get down with pop any more? Let them soothe you back into what made it addictive in the first place. Let Lucius prove that music still exists--simply and sincerely.

Oh please... if you would just pull up a copy of the latest UAW contract, you'd know that there is no more GM-sponsored healthcare for retirees, that a two-tiered wage system for the active employees is now in place, that wages were frozen, that the COLA was eliminated, and work rules were reworked to allow management a much higher degree of flexibility. Four assembly plants were closed, costing thousands of jobs (although one has been partially reopened). Loss of efficiency? Again, oh please! I suppose that you've never been inside an automotive assembly plant, so I'll instruct you that the lines run at a rate of 50-70 cars per hour, and each worker has a variety of tasks to perform. Every company has invested heavily in robotics and other means of automation. Even before the bankruptcy, machinery was being installed that operated more efficiently; jobs that once required 4 workers were suddenly being done with one or two workers. That trend continues today.

One more thing that continues to puzzle me... just how much did the $10.5 billion cost each individual taxpayer? I've been told there are about 190 million taxpayers (???) in the U.S. Again, I was told that figuring on that basis, the GM bailout ended up with an average cost of under $70 per taxpayer ($1.30 approximately per week.) While I have no figures available to me to back that up, I do have a feeling that the $10.5 billion, while seemingly a large number, did not cost each and every taxpayer all that much.

GM employs some 77,000 people here in the U.S. all are tax payers themselves is a return on the 10 billion lost in the recent pay back in the future. If you could only grasp the trouble our country was in back in September of 2008; America and the world came within 48 hours of losing everything, if those banks had failed and the government had not step in. The United States and the world would have been in total Chaos. The auto bailout alone saved 1.5 million jobs in the United States.

Consumers were, and are, loathe to buy a vehicle from a company being strangled by oppressive union contracts.

As a GM/ UAW retiree, your inference that the Japanese have beaten us with "honor" and "respect" is , well, a bit farcical. The Japanese and Koreans may well have had us on the ropes in the 80s, 90s and early 2000s, but our vehicles are very competitive with the very best of the foreign auto companies now. The Japanese, and the Koreans, were and are very tough competitors, and it was that toughness and attention to detail that made their companies what they were. Honor and respect? I don't know, judging from the way Toyota handled (how about totally mangled) the issue of sudden acceleration a few years back, and Toyota and Honda have been absolutely dogged by recall issues both in the U.S. and worldwide in the recent past, I wouldn't give them too high of marks as far as integrity goes. While I do agree with your assessment of GM management in the past, and as much as I hate to admit it, there was a systemic problem in that past, one that I'm told has been addressed quite thoroughly. GM is a much different company now; management and production workers both saw what oblivion looked like, and it is very fresh in their memories.

I'd argue strenuously that "the Japanese have beaten us at our own game" considering that all cars are built with supplier parts sourced from the U.S. and abroad, and there is literally no car built with totally U.S. or Japanese parts. If you are "loath" to buy a GM product, fine, but let reality guide your purchase of another brand, not emotion.
Japanese car makers are also 100% union.

"The announcement of the sale brought a collective sigh of relief from G.M. officials, who have struggled to win back consumers who were loath to buy a vehicle from an automaker under the yoke of government ownership"

The above sentence, a strange sentence from the above article. I thought consumers were loath to buy a vehicle from an automaker that has lost touch with consumer's interests. Loath to buy products from a company whose management had fallen to decadence. Loath to buy vehicles from a company that lost touch with it's mission. Loath to buy vehicles from a company whose management has leveled blame on it's workers rather than examine the troubles at the top. I don't know if I'll ever be able to trust GM again.

The Japanese have beaten us at our own game with two simple words, "honor" and "respect."

Being a felon makes you more or less unemployable in many places in the U.S., especially in an economy that doesn't have enough jobs for anyone. Black men are incarcerated for drug offenses at an astonishing rate, rendering them outcasts in the workplace, and they are keeping a for-profit prison system operational while warehousing people who never really stood a chance in the dwindling economy. (See the 2012 documentary The House I Live In or the HBO series The Wire if you need more info.)

As for the EIC, you do have to have earned income to get the credit, but predatory American capitalism being what it is, a whole industry--tax refund loans--has sprung up to skim as much money as it can from this federal program that was intended to alleviate poverty. Mother Jones did an interesting story on this in 2011. http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2011/04/gary-rivlin-tax-prep-refund-...

When you see those Liberty Tax offices spring up in February, know that wealthy people are ripping off the poor and American taxpayers at the same time.

No doubt the parents in this story are suboptimal, but why not save your judgment and ire for those who really deserve it.

Really well written.
As always, I feel sorry for the kids.
This family has ten kids (counting the other two the man has outside the marriage) and overwhelmed drug addicts as parents. It takes incredible skill, patience, wealth and ingenuity to raise ten kids. The billionaires and millionaires of the city didn't make two uneducated, incapable, drug addled parents have ten children. And though the article may blame elitist policies on failing Dasani, did the generous policies before Bloomberg do any better? Looking at Dasani's mom, one would have to say no. Ample room in shelter, plenty of city programs back in the day and she still made the worst possible choices. Her oldest daughter has got to wake up and get the children of an unemployed woman with no responsibility ready for school. What's the answer? Lots of support and Dasani's mom still choose crime and continual pregnancy.. No support-same outcome.
What are the uncomfortable truths here? All the money in the world won't solve the problems of a lifetime of bad choices? We've got to stop paying people with the least ability to raise kids to have them? That these kids would probably be better off in an orphanage?

Here is an obvious reply to Paul's "What reason is there to think that if women had had the same resources as men for the last 5000 years there wouldn't be just as many female contributions as male? And wouldn't the latter arrangement be more just?"

My reply: One of the great problems with modern feminism is feminists say women are equal in ability to men but simultaneously say women have been oppressed over the centuries and have not been able to demonstrate their ability. Quite obviously if women have not been able to demonstrate their ability we cannot have any basis for saying women are equal in ability to men--we cannot know that fact. We have to FIRST give women a chance to determine if they are equal in every way. That is just common sense.

But you Paul, and apparently the 10 people who agreed with you say automatically without any clear evidential basis that women are not only equal in ability to men they would have contributed as equally as men over the centuries if not for men.

Paul, just because I have no overpowering reason for supposing women would not have had equal contributions to men if they had had a chance over the centuries does not at all mean they are equal in ability. You, Paul, have no overpowering reason for supposing they would have been equal in contribution. We quite simply have no historical record for demonstrating either way. Basic logic. The fact is we are finding out more and more every day abilities of men and women.

Because foster care won't resolve any of the problems. First, the 8 children will all be split up. Second, the children won't have any stability in foster care as most children are moved multiple times. Third, foster care doesn't guarantee a better living situation. There are many foster families who take in kids just for that monthly check - upwards of $1000. Fourth, the taxpayer spends even more money on a foster care removals & placements. Between the payments to the various foster homes, travel expenses, removal proceedings & executions (with police in tow), family court sessions equipped with lawyers, advocates, social workers and child psychologists, the bill can total $100K+ just for one case. And the abject poverty still exists!! If Dasani is still in foster care when she turns 18, her case is closed and the child welfare agency no longer funds her. At that time, she then goes to either live back with her birth mother or she turns to the streets. Hopefully at that time, she'll have contact with her 7 siblings.

The problem here is that people are expected to find work in a private sector that doesn't need them. It's hard to find a job even if you have qualifications and experience. I think it's a real shame that we don't have public jobs of different kinds. It seems to me that there is a lot of work to be done in New York. (How about keeping that shelter clean and repaired for a start, but for some reason there is never any money.)
This is the Puritan philosophy carried over from the 1600s.

I am always amazed by comments like yours, and how common they are.

Many, many, studies have shown a direct correlation between rising standards of living and a lower birth rate. In that order. It happens in every society all over the world.

If Dasani receives the resources she needs to fulfill even some of her promise, it is highly unlikely that she will have seven children.

It is so easy to cast stones.

Under Bloomberg, NYC schools were forced spend millions and millions on tests and senseless data gathering  instead of paying councilors, social services, after school support, and health services, all of which are needed to to help children such as these and to lift them up. School budgets have been slashed while the rich get richer here. This needs to change for all of our sakes.

As a black woman, I can tell you that the reason for the divide between poor and rich blacks is location. The majority of poor Blacks are now located in large urban areas. The upwardly mobile Blacks have left urban cities and are not looking back.  We used to help each other out much more in the past because all Blacks, regardless of economic & social status, were located together because of segregation. Now, just like Whites, we can choose to distance ourselves from whomever we think are "undesirable".
Actually if Malcolm and Martin were still alive, they'd place responsibility on the parents.

Two unemployed, high school drop-outs with drug addiction problems....AND EIGHT CHILDREN! Dear God!

My heart aches for the children. But, I am angry at the parent's choices, their neglect of the children and their life long dependence on public assistance totaling hundred of thousands, maybe millions of dollars.

Without parents or family to take care of them, the children would be better off in foster care. I don't like the idea of separating children from parents and siblings from one another, but foster care or adoption are the best options.They will be fed, housed, clothed, receive medical care, have greater stability and a chance for a better life.

Leaving them with parents who can't or won't parent them is neither responsible or loving.

I'm willing to spend the money on innocent children; not on the parent's lifelong pattern of irresponsible, self destructive behaviors.
